------------------------------

National Human Trafficking Hotline - 24/7 Confidential

[1-888-373-7888](tel:1-888-373-7888)[233733](tel:233733)[More Information on human trafficking in Maryland](https://goccp.maryland.gov/victims/rights-resources/human-trafficking/)

Customer Service Promise
------------------------

The State of Maryland pledges to provide constituents, businesses, customers, and stakeholders with friendly and courteous, timely and responsive, accurate and consistent, accessible and convenient, and truthful and transparent services.

[Take Our Survey](http://www.maryland.gov/pages/customerservice.aspx)

Help Stop Fraud in State Government
-----------------------------------

The Maryland General Assembly’s Office of Legislative Audits operates a toll-free fraud hotline to receive allegations of fraud and/or abuse of State government resources. Information reported to the hotline in the past has helped to eliminate certain fraudulent activities and protect State resources.

[More Information](https://www.ola.state.md.us/fraud/ola-fraud-hotline/)

Customer Service Promise
------------------------

The State of Maryland pledges to provide constituents, businesses, customers, and stakeholders with friendly and courteous, timely and responsive, accurate and consistent, accessible and convenient, and truthful and transparent services.

[Take Our Survey](http://www.maryland.gov/pages/customerservice.aspx)

Help Stop Fraud in State Government
-----------------------------------

The Maryland General Assembly’s Office of Legislative Audits operates a toll-free fraud hotline to receive allegations of fraud and/or abuse of State government resources. Information reported to the hotline in the past has helped to eliminate certain fraudulent activities and protect State resources.

[More Information](https://www.ola.state.md.us/fraud/ola-fraud-hotline/)

##### Google Translate Disclaimer

The Maryland Department of Information Technology (“DoIT”) offers translations of the content through Google Translate. Because Google Translate is an external website, DoIT does not control the quality or accuracy of translated content. All DoIT content is filtered through Google Translate which may result in unexpected and unpredictable degradation of portions of text, images and the general appearance on translated pages. Google Translate may maintain unique privacy and use policies. These policies are not controlled by DoIT and are not associated with DoIT’s privacy and use policies. After selecting a translation option, users will be notified that they are leaving DoIT’s website. Users should consult the original English content on DoIT’s website if there are any questions about the translated content.

Title: Washington, DC Crime Rates

URL Source: https://www.neighborhoodscout.com/dc/washington/crime

Published Time: 2025-04-04T20:07:20+00:00

Markdown Content:
With a crime rate of 60 per one thousand residents, Washington has one of the highest crime rates in America compared to all communities of all sizes - from the smallest towns to the very largest cities. One's chance of becoming a victim of either violent or property crime here is one in 17. However, compared to other communities of similar population size, Washington has a crime rate that is noticeably lower than the average. This means that for comparably sized cities all across America, Washington is actually safer than most according to NeighborhoodScout's exclusive analysis of FBI crime data. The crime data that NeighborhoodScout used for this analysis are the seven offenses from the uniform crime reports, collected by the FBI from 18,000 local law enforcement agencies, and include both violent and property crimes, combined. Now let us turn to take a look at how Washington does for violent crimes specifically, and then how it does for property crimes. This is important because the overall crime rate can be further illuminated by understanding if violent crime or property crimes (or both) are the major contributors to the general rate of crime in Washington. For Washington, we found that the violent crime rate is one of the highest in the nation, across communities of all sizes (both large and small). Violent offenses tracked included rape, murder and non-negligent manslaughter, armed robbery, and aggravated assault, including assault with a deadly weapon. According to NeighborhoodScout's analysis of FBI reported crime data, your chance of becoming a victim of one of these crimes in Washington is one in 75. Significantly, based on the number of murders reported by the FBI and the number of residents living in the city, NeighborhoodScout's analysis shows that Washington experiences one of the higher murder rates in the nation when compared with cities and towns for all sizes of population, from the largest to the smallest. NeighborhoodScout's analysis also reveals that Washington's rate for property crime is 47 per one thousand population. This makes Washington a place where there is an above average chance of becoming a victim of a property crime, when compared to all other communities in America of all population sizes. Property crimes are motor vehicle theft, arson, larceny, and burglary. Your chance of becoming a victim of any of these crimes in Washington is one in 21.

With a crime rate of 52 per one thousand residents, Washington has one of the highest crime rates in America compared to all communities of all sizes - from the smallest towns to the very largest cities. One's chance of becoming a victim of either violent or property crime here is one in 19. Within District Of Columbia, more than 100% of the communities have a lower crime rate than Washington. In fact, after researching dangerous places to live, NeighborhoodScout found Washington to be one of the [top 100 most dangerous cities in the U.S.A.](https://www.neighborhoodscout.com/blog/top100dangerous)

Importantly, when you compare Washington to other communities of similar population, then Washington crime rate (violent and property crimes combined) is quite a bit higher than average. Regardless of how Washington does relative to all communities in America of all sizes, when NeighborhoodScout compared it to communities of similar population size, its crime rate per thousand residents stands out as higher than most.

Now let us turn to take a look at how Washington does for violent crimes specifically, and then how it does for property crimes. This is important because the overall crime rate can be further illuminated by understanding if violent crime or property crimes (or both) are the major contributors to the general rate of crime in Washington.

For Washington, we found that the violent crime rate is one of the highest in the nation, across communities of all sizes (both large and small). Violent offenses tracked included rape, murder and non-negligent manslaughter, armed robbery, and aggravated assault, including assault with a deadly weapon. According to NeighborhoodScout's analysis of FBI reported crime data, your chance of becoming a victim of one of these crimes in Washington is one in 95.

Significantly, based on the number of murders reported by the FBI and the number of residents living in the city, NeighborhoodScout's analysis shows that Washington experiences one of the higher murder rates in the nation when compared with cities and towns for all sizes of population, from the largest to the smallest.

In addition, NeighborhoodScout found that a lot of the crime that takes place in Washington is property crime. Property crimes that are tracked for this analysis are burglary, larceny over fifty dollars, motor vehicle theft, and arson. In Washington, your chance of becoming a victim of a property crime is one in 24, which is a rate of 42 per one thousand population.

Importantly, we found that Washington has one of the highest rates of motor vehicle theft in the nation according to our analysis of FBI crime data. This is compared to communities of all sizes, from the smallest to the largest. In fact, your chance of getting your car stolen if you live in Washington is one in 99.

With a crime rate of 59 per one thousand residents, Baltimore has one of the highest crime rates in America compared to all communities of all sizes - from the smallest towns to the very largest cities. One's chance of becoming a victim of either violent or property crime here is one in 17. Within Maryland, more than 99% of the communities have a lower crime rate than Baltimore. In fact, after researching dangerous places to live, NeighborhoodScout found Baltimore to be one of the [top 100 most dangerous cities in the U.S.A.](https://www.neighborhoodscout.com/blog/top100dangerous)

Importantly, when you compare Baltimore to other communities of similar population, then Baltimore crime rate (violent and property crimes combined) is quite a bit higher than average. Regardless of how Baltimore does relative to all communities in America of all sizes, when NeighborhoodScout compared it to communities of similar population size, its crime rate per thousand residents stands out as higher than most.

Now let us turn to take a look at how Baltimore does for violent crimes specifically, and then how it does for property crimes. This is important because the overall crime rate can be further illuminated by understanding if violent crime or property crimes (or both) are the major contributors to the general rate of crime in Baltimore.

For Baltimore, we found that the violent crime rate is one of the highest in the nation, across communities of all sizes (both large and small). Violent offenses tracked included rape, murder and non-negligent manslaughter, armed robbery, and aggravated assault, including assault with a deadly weapon. According to NeighborhoodScout's analysis of FBI reported crime data, your chance of becoming a victim of one of these crimes in Baltimore is one in 63.

Significantly, based on the number of murders reported by the FBI and the number of residents living in the city, NeighborhoodScout's analysis shows that Baltimore experiences one of the higher murder rates in the nation when compared with cities and towns for all sizes of population, from the largest to the smallest.

In addition, NeighborhoodScout found that a lot of the crime that takes place in Baltimore is property crime. Property crimes that are tracked for this analysis are burglary, larceny over fifty dollars, motor vehicle theft, and arson. In Baltimore, your chance of becoming a victim of a property crime is one in 23, which is a rate of 43 per one thousand population.

Importantly, we found that Baltimore has one of the highest rates of motor vehicle theft in the nation according to our analysis of FBI crime data. This is compared to communities of all sizes, from the smallest to the largest. In fact, your chance of getting your car stolen if you live in Baltimore is one in 54.

Source & Methodology

×
**Analytics built by:**[Location, Inc.](https://www.locationinc.com/)

**Raw data sources:** 18,000 local law enforcement agencies in the U.S.

**Date(s) & Update Frequency:** Reflects 2023 calendar year; released from FBI in October 2024 (latest available). Updated annually. [Where is 2024 data?](https://help.neighborhoodscout.com/support/solutions/articles/25000001993-how-current-is-your-crime-data-)

**Methodology:** Our nationwide meta-analysis overcomes the issues inherent in any crime database, including non-reporting and reporting errors. This is possible by associating the 9.4 million reported crimes in the U.S, including over 2 million geocoded point locations…. [Read more about Scout's Crime Data](https://www.neighborhoodscout.com/about-the-data/crime-rates)

*   [data](https://www.neighborhoodscout.com/md/college-park/crime#data)
*   [description](https://www.neighborhoodscout.com/md/college-park/crime#description)

The crime rate in College Park is considerably higher than the national average across all communities in America from the largest to the smallest, although at 26 crimes per one thousand residents, it is not among the communities with the very highest crime rate. The chance of becoming a victim of either violent or property crime in College Park is 1 in 38. Based on FBI crime data, College Park is not one of the safest communities in America. Relative to Maryland, College Park has a crime rate that is higher than 82% of the state's cities and towns of all sizes.

Importantly, when you compare College Park to other communities of similar population, then College Park crime rate (violent and property crimes combined) is quite a bit higher than average. Regardless of how College Park does relative to all communities in America of all sizes, when NeighborhoodScout compared it to communities of similar population size, its crime rate per thousand residents stands out as higher than most.

Now let us turn to take a look at how College Park does for violent crimes specifically, and then how it does for property crimes. This is important because the overall crime rate can be further illuminated by understanding if violent crime or property crimes (or both) are the major contributors to the general rate of crime in College Park.

From our analysis, we discovered that violent crime in College Park occurs at a rate higher than in most communities of all population sizes in America. The chance that a person will become a victim of a violent crime in College Park; such as armed robbery, aggravated assault, rape or murder; is 1 in 314. This equates to a rate of 3 per one thousand inhabitants.

NeighborhoodScout's analysis also reveals that College Park's rate for property crime is 23 per one thousand population. This makes College Park a place where there is an above average chance of becoming a victim of a property crime, when compared to all other communities in America of all population sizes. Property crimes are motor vehicle theft, arson, larceny, and burglary. Your chance of becoming a victim of any of these crimes in College Park is one in 43.

Importantly, we found that College Park has one of the highest rates of motor vehicle theft in the nation according to our analysis of FBI crime data. This is compared to communities of all sizes, from the smallest to the largest. In fact, your chance of getting your car stolen if you live in College Park is one in 117.

data (https://www.neighborhoodscout.com/md/greenbelt/crime#data)
description (https://www.neighborhoodscout.com/md/greenbelt/crime#description)
With a crime rate of 63 per one thousand residents, Greenbelt has one of the highest crime rates in America compared to all communities of all sizes - from the smallest towns to the very largest cities. One's chance of becoming a victim of either violent or property crime here is one in 16. Within Maryland, more than 99% of the communities have a lower crime rate than Greenbelt.
Separately, it is always interesting and important to compare a city's crime rate with those of similarly sized communities - a fair comparison as larger cities tend to have more crime. NeighborhoodScout has done just that. With a population of 24,360, Greenbelt has a combined rate of violent and property crime that is very high compared to other places of similar population size. Regardless of whether Greenbelt does well or poorly compared to all other cities and towns in the US of all sizes, compared to places with a similar population, it fares badly. Few other communities of this size have a crime rate as high as Greenbelt.
Now let us turn to take a look at how Greenbelt does for violent crimes specifically, and then how it does for property crimes. This is important because the overall crime rate can be further illuminated by understanding if violent crime or property crimes (or both) are the major contributors to the general rate of crime in Greenbelt.
For Greenbelt, we found that the violent crime rate is one of the highest in the nation, across communities of all sizes (both large and small). Violent offenses tracked included rape, murder and non-negligent manslaughter, armed robbery, and aggravated assault, including assault with a deadly weapon. According to NeighborhoodScout's analysis of FBI reported crime data, your chance of becoming a victim of one of these crimes in Greenbelt is one in 145.
In addition, NeighborhoodScout found that a lot of the crime that takes place in Greenbelt is property crime. Property crimes that are tracked for this analysis are burglary, larceny over fifty dollars, motor vehicle theft, and arson. In Greenbelt, your chance of becoming a victim of a property crime is one in 18, which is a rate of 56 per one thousand population.
Importantly, we found that Greenbelt has one of the highest rates of motor vehicle theft in the nation according to our analysis of FBI crime data. This is compared to communities of all sizes, from the smallest to the largest. In fact, your chance of getting your car stolen if you live in Greenbelt is one in 49.

description (https://www.neighborhoodscout.com/md/jessup/crime#description)
The crime rate in Jessup is considerably higher than the national average across all communities in America from the largest to the smallest, although at 16 crimes per one thousand residents, it is not among the communities with the very highest crime rate. The chance of becoming a victim of either violent or property crime in Jessup is 1 in 62. Based on FBI crime data, Jessup is not one of the safest communities in America. Relative to Maryland, Jessup has a crime rate that is higher than 65% of the state's cities and towns of all sizes.
How does the crime rate in Jessup compare to similar sized communities across America? When NeighborhoodScout compared Jessup with other communities its size, we found that the crime rate was near the average for all other communities of similar size. So, whether Jessup's crime rate is high or low compared to all places in the US, when we control for population size and compare it to places that are similar in size, it is near the middle of the pack in crime rate; not much more or less dangerous, and about what we would expect from the statistics.
Now let us turn to take a look at how Jessup does for violent crimes specifically, and then how it does for property crimes. This is important because the overall crime rate can be further illuminated by understanding if violent crime or property crimes (or both) are the major contributors to the general rate of crime in Jessup.
From our analysis, we discovered that violent crime in Jessup occurs at a rate higher than in most communities of all population sizes in America. The chance that a person will become a victim of a violent crime in Jessup; such as armed robbery, aggravated assault, rape or murder; is 1 in 458. This equates to a rate of 2 per one thousand inhabitants.
NeighborhoodScout's analysis also reveals that Jessup's rate for property crime is 14 per one thousand population.  This makes Jessup a place where there is an above average chance of becoming a victim of a property crime, when compared to all other communities in America of all population sizes. Property crimes are motor vehicle theft, arson, larceny, and burglary. Your chance of becoming a victim of any of these crimes in Jessup is one in 71.

description (https://www.neighborhoodscout.com/md/laurel/crime#description)
With a crime rate of 51 per one thousand residents, Laurel has one of the highest crime rates in America compared to all communities of all sizes - from the smallest towns to the very largest cities. One's chance of becoming a victim of either violent or property crime here is one in 20. Within Maryland, more than 96% of the communities have a lower crime rate than Laurel.
Separately, it is always interesting and important to compare a city's crime rate with those of similarly sized communities - a fair comparison as larger cities tend to have more crime. NeighborhoodScout has done just that. With a population of 29,400, Laurel has a combined rate of violent and property crime that is very high compared to other places of similar population size. Regardless of whether Laurel does well or poorly compared to all other cities and towns in the US of all sizes, compared to places with a similar population, it fares badly. Few other communities of this size have a crime rate as high as Laurel.
Now let us turn to take a look at how Laurel does for violent crimes specifically, and then how it does for property crimes. This is important because the overall crime rate can be further illuminated by understanding if violent crime or property crimes (or both) are the major contributors to the general rate of crime in Laurel.
For Laurel, we found that the violent crime rate is one of the highest in the nation, across communities of all sizes (both large and small). Violent offenses tracked included rape, murder and non-negligent manslaughter, armed robbery, and aggravated assault, including assault with a deadly weapon. According to NeighborhoodScout's analysis of FBI reported crime data, your chance of becoming a victim of one of these crimes in Laurel is one in 150.
In addition, NeighborhoodScout found that a lot of the crime that takes place in Laurel is property crime. Property crimes that are tracked for this analysis are burglary, larceny over fifty dollars, motor vehicle theft, and arson. In Laurel, your chance of becoming a victim of a property crime is one in 22, which is a rate of 44 per one thousand population.
Importantly, we found that Laurel has one of the highest rates of motor vehicle theft in the nation according to our analysis of FBI crime data. This is compared to communities of all sizes, from the smallest to the largest. In fact, your chance of getting your car stolen if you live in Laurel is one in 92.

FAQ on NeighborhoodScout's Crime Data
NeighborhoodScout® provides exclusive crime risk analytics for every neighborhood in America with up to 98% predictive accuracy. Crime risk indices are nationally comparable on a 1 – 100 scale, where 100 means safer than 100% of U.S. neighborhoods.

With a crime rate of 36 per one thousand residents, Riverdale has one of the highest crime rates in America compared to all communities of all sizes - from the smallest towns to the very largest cities. One's chance of becoming a victim of either violent or property crime here is one in 28. Within Maryland, more than 91% of the communities have a lower crime rate than Riverdale.

Separately, it is always interesting and important to compare a town's crime rate with those of similarly sized communities - a fair comparison as larger cities tend to have more crime. NeighborhoodScout has done just that. With a population of 7,164, Riverdale has a combined rate of violent and property crime that is very high compared to other places of similar population size. Regardless of whether Riverdale does well or poorly compared to all other cities and towns in the US of all sizes, compared to places with a similar population, it fares badly. Few other communities of this size have a crime rate as high as Riverdale.

Now let us turn to take a look at how Riverdale does for violent crimes specifically, and then how it does for property crimes. This is important because the overall crime rate can be further illuminated by understanding if violent crime or property crimes (or both) are the major contributors to the general rate of crime in Riverdale.

For Riverdale, we found that the violent crime rate is one of the highest in the nation, across communities of all sizes (both large and small). Violent offenses tracked included rape, murder and non-negligent manslaughter, armed robbery, and aggravated assault, including assault with a deadly weapon. According to NeighborhoodScout's analysis of FBI reported crime data, your chance of becoming a victim of one of these crimes in Riverdale is one in 159.

In addition, NeighborhoodScout found that a lot of the crime that takes place in Riverdale is property crime. Property crimes that are tracked for this analysis are burglary, larceny over fifty dollars, motor vehicle theft, and arson. In Riverdale, your chance of becoming a victim of a property crime is one in 34, which is a rate of 30 per one thousand population.

Importantly, we found that Riverdale has one of the highest rates of motor vehicle theft in the nation according to our analysis of FBI crime data. This is compared to communities of all sizes, from the smallest to the largest. In fact, your chance of getting your car stolen if you live in Riverdale is one in 116.

The crime rate in Savage is considerably higher than the national average across all communities in America from the largest to the smallest, although at 21 crimes per one thousand residents, it is not among the communities with the very highest crime rate. The chance of becoming a victim of either violent or property crime in Savage is 1 in 48. Based on FBI crime data, Savage is not one of the safest communities in America. Relative to Maryland, Savage has a crime rate that is higher than 74% of the state's cities and towns of all sizes.
Importantly, when you compare Savage to other communities of similar population, then Savage crime rate (violent and property crimes combined) is quite a bit higher than average. Regardless of how Savage does relative to all communities in America of all sizes, when NeighborhoodScout compared it to communities of similar population size, its crime rate per thousand residents stands out as higher than most.
Now let us turn to take a look at how Savage does for violent crimes specifically, and then how it does for property crimes. This is important because the overall crime rate can be further illuminated by understanding if violent crime or property crimes (or both) are the major contributors to the general rate of crime in Savage.
From our analysis, we discovered that violent crime in Savage occurs at a rate higher than in most communities of all population sizes in America. The chance that a person will become a victim of a violent crime in Savage; such as armed robbery, aggravated assault, rape or murder; is 1 in 580. This equates to a rate of 2 per one thousand inhabitants.
NeighborhoodScout's analysis also reveals that Savage's rate for property crime is 19 per one thousand population.  This makes Savage a place where there is an above average chance of becoming a victim of a property crime, when compared to all other communities in America of all population sizes. Property crimes are motor vehicle theft, arson, larceny, and burglary. Your chance of becoming a victim of any of these crimes in Savage is one in 52.
Importantly, we found that Savage has one of the highest rates of motor vehicle theft in the nation according to our analysis of FBI crime data. This is compared to communities of all sizes, from the smallest to the largest. In fact, your chance of getting your car stolen if you live in Savage is one in 269.
